body:
This is a bit scary, I'll have to run exhaustive tests. I'm not convinced that `setuptools` with `extras_require` will do the right thing (installing pymysql) without a glitch. 

Maybe the solution is to `try:` importing MySQLdb and fall back on pymysql, at least until we release Airflow `2.0.0`. The `setup.py` can only reference pymysql, but at least we don't break existing installs.

I double checked that the fancy cursors are supported by pymysql. Luckily it looks like the author has kept the same interface.
The only thing missing thing is a sarcastic `logging.warning` message about using FTP in 2015 :)
I would recommend http://metricsgraphicsjs.org/ for this. The mozilla license is a bit more favorable.

Hi @LilithWittmann 
Sure, am looking into it. 
Btw (kindly excuse for lack of python expertise) how do you start airflow from github repo? I installed airflow from sudo pip install and it does not have my changes yet. So I cannot verify where and what error is seen for missing mesos libraries.

It looks like Highchart's definition of "non-commercial" isn't what I though it was. I'm not even sure it's in line with the creative commons specs. We also might be able to get a blessing from them, though it might just be easier to rip it out. 

I've used this lib before: http://nvd3.org/
@kapil-malik I'm trying to find out the same atm. ;-). (Ok first I should find out why I can't install pandas in a virtual environment on my  laptop :-/)
Ok I will try to replace highcharts with one of these libraries (and maybe refactor the javascript part a bit ;-) )

Nice !
+1 for REST APIs, it will be helpful to have read/query APIs to list DAGs / jobs and their status etc.

Also, do you think it's possible that different steps of a DAG may have different resource requirements? Say for example memory ? I am a beginner in python, but I assume it would have a concept of specifying the requirements, just like we can do in java (via Xmx etc.).
Further, for distributed resource schedulers (Yarn / mesos / kubernetes / GCE etc.), even cpu cores / disk can be specified. Although I am afraid those specifications might not be applicable for local executors. So the behavior will differ with envts (rather undesirable).

One more thing, do you have plans for UI for defining a DAG? say some sort of drag drop which allows to select from available operators and allows for setting their properties (and for using xcom within DAG)

Used http://python-future.org/overview.html#futurize-2-to-both for mesos_executor.py,
Fixed installation.rst so that the bulleted list looks less ugly
:) raised https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/pull/426 for py2 -> py3

@jlowin After I dug into it more, I'm not a fan of how the logs are stored on the filesystem for each worker. On top of that, each worker has to spin up a webserver to serve the logs back to the main ui process. I'm thinking of building an adapter where you can specify where the logs can be stored. It would be up to that adapter to define how to query the underlying data store to get the logs back out. Not sure if this makes sense.
Oh wow! that is ambitious. Sorry about my javascript :)

Just want to flag that this relates to some discussion re: triggered DAGs in https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/issues/289 (and now the roadmap!) - in many cases when triggering a DAG for an on-demand analysis, it would be handy to pass some metadata that was accessible to DAG tasks.  Viewed in this way, there are a lot of common semantics between backfill use cases and on-demand use cases.

@kapil-malik  be careful with mentioning drag and drop ... @mistercrunch has strong opinions about it :)
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/335167/9973783/dd9ef070-5e2d-11e5-8be0-9e65ba6c8589.png)

Oh ok .. 

![Oh ok](http://cdn.smosh.com/sites/default/files/ftpuploads/bloguploads/0513/funny-avengers-gif-loki-huaaagh2.gif)

Well I completely echo the [sentiment](http://nerds.airbnb.com/airflow) behind python based authoring, I was only wondering if it'd add to adoption rate if people could manage e2e flow in UI (authoring, execution, logs). :)

@kapil-malik to install directly from github: `pip install git+https://github.com/airbnb/airflow.git[@optional_branch_name][#egg=optional_reference_name]`

Or to work with local files: `pip install -e path/to/airflow/repo` (any local changes will be automatically picked up next time you import because of the `-e` flag)
@mistercrunch What a wonderful world this would be...

@kapil-malik about resources containment it will have to be some sort of integration with executors that support it. I had a brainstorm session talking about leveraging the JVM through using Jython only on the worker side for specific operators that would be stamped "jython compatible". I don't have a good sense on how complicated or feasible this is....

About the DAG generation from the UI I think I'd like to have something like that that would generate generate python code (to force the user to deal with the code and not bypass code review), and probably more form/CRUD based than drag/drop... It isn't a priority unless the community gets behind it.

Joining can now be achieve with "trigger rules":
http://pythonhosted.org/airflow/concepts.html#trigger-rules

`start_date` really means "first run". Each run (aka `execution_date`) need to line up perfectly for dependencies to be met. 

If you want to delay t2 by 30 minutes the airflow way, you'd use a TimeSensor (as say `t3`) and have t2 depend on t3. All these tasks would have the same `start_date`.

Make sense? Where do you think I should change the docs to clarify this?

Yes, regarding resource requirements, I also thought whether it would be better to add them to BaseOperator, or have specific Operators. For example, Yarn / mesos executors could very well support this for say 'Docker Operators'.
While this might look too narrow / specific for original 'Airflow' users, I believe it will be extremely useful for original 'Yarn / Mesos / GCE' users, who are out there looking for a better workflow management solution. Yarn still has Oozie, but we have no such alternative in mesos (no offense to Chronos). Airflow can fill that space very nicely (and oh that would be such a relief), but by restricting to specific operators which take inputs more aligned with mesos.

Clearly the best option is to add a parameter to `BaseOperator` that would be called `executor_config` or something, and the format is specified in the the executor's documentation. The format could be an object, a data structure, a reference to a server-side template, or whatever makes sense in the context of the executor.

Celery clearly has little or no support for this. At Airbnb we're planning on writing a YarnExecutor in the next few months.

@jlowin, many thanks for the pointer. I think we should add it to install documentation as well.
@LilithWittmann I just installed airflow from latest git repository, without mesos libraries on a fresh box. It works perfectly fine for me (`airflow initdb`, `airflow webserver`, `airflow scheduler`)

Thanks, that's really help! 
And the `start_date` is really a confused concept for new users,  "start date" and "start time" is really different.
Maybe some more description for the parameter `start_date` at `class BaseOperator(object)` in models.py is better:

``` python
:param start_date: start date for the task, the scheduler will start from this point in time. 
All the tasks in one dag should have the same start 'time'
:type start_date: datetime
```

Ok, I (re)implemented some of the chart types:
- line
- bar (grouped, stacked)
- column (grouped, stacked)
- stacked area (stacked, stream, expanded)

but I have no idea how to implement the others (esp. heatmap and parallel coordinates) with nvd3 /o\
You can find my branch here: https://github.com/LilithWittmann/airflow/tree/new_chart_libary

Nice!

Parallel coordinate is one of those d3 examples, the license looks ok there. For heatmap we can probably just remove the feature.

Now there's a few views in the application itself (landing times and duration charts). The Gantt chart might be a git more tricky but it isn't too hard to reproduce while hacking a line chart. I'm hoping I can get to this sometime next week.

This should make it very clear:
https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/commit/00f3f69b61bca55ad69e0a17e15713a708355f33

Hitching onto this issue, a related question: Does @mistercrunch's answer imply the scheduler now picks up previously successful task instances if they are cleared (either in the CLI or the UI)? I'm confused because the docs state re: the scheduler `It will not fill in gaps; it only moves forward in time from the latest task instance on that task`
Please take a look @kapil-malik @mistercrunch

Looks good to me. Thanks @wndhydrnt 
@mistercrunch can tell more about storing generic key-value pairs. Can [Variables](http://pythonhosted.org/airflow/concepts.html#variables) serve the purpose?
Can also add section on Community Contributed Executors :)

I have done some further work on the kerberos support (https://github.com/bolkedebruin/airflow - kerberos branch). The HiveCliHook with beeline now works with kerberos (tested). To get it to work make sure you generate a key tab for airflow and put something like this in your airflow.cfg

`[security]
keytab = /etc/airflow/airflow.keytab
reinit_frequency = 3600
enabled = True`

then for the hive_cli connections add something like this:

`{ "use_beeline": true, "principal": "hive/_HOST@EXAMPLE.COM"}`. 

_HOST gets replaced by the fqdn of the server airflow is running on. Replace EXAMPLE.COM with your realm.

Furthermore you will need an "airflow kerberos" instance running for every worker. Celery stuff is working yet (ie. I havent looked at it yet).

Let me know what you think.
What are your thoughts on using disque rather than redis as broker?

Define a new dag in a python file, for example [tutorial](pythonhosted.org/airflow/tutorial.html) and paste it in the dags_folder (by default ~/airflow/dags ). When a task in DAG runs for next time (via scheduler), it will show up in the UI.
@kapil-malik, right, I just need to install the mesos libs in order to compile the docs with the executor.

If you mean as a broker for Celery, Disque doesn't seem to be documented here:
http://celery.readthedocs.org/en/latest/getting-started/brokers/
oh ok ...
Can confirm -- it's because the svg id can't contain periods. One hack that seems to work is to replace `".`' with `"__dot__"` in the dag_id string.

Yeah I'm not 100% sure on what the intent was, @smarden1 ?

I don't think that the base class needs this, but it's ok to add extra params (with sensible defaults) to individual hooks' methods.
#430 might fix this once merged by removing the import statements in `contrib/__init__.py`

Hi,
Thank you for such great product as airflow.
I would like to speculate about "Externally Triggered DAGs". You've mentioned "genome", "data scientist" I'm working as bioinformatician for the last 4 years and I feel that useful, easy to install and configure workflow system is really the problem. So my speculation is about tools that bioinformatician usually run. The diversity of tools is incredible java/python/R/C++/perl based, some of them output the result into stdout some of them can put a bunch of files into current dir or relative to current subfolder. The names of output files can depend on input file/s name or be separated one. The organization of pipeline is not only the order of tools but also some logic, like, in one step we can mark some replicates on the other we can do analysis with or without replicates and based on result choose the best solution and produce output. Usually it is good to make different branches for later analysis if something wrong and repeat from specific position and downstream to save a time.

So my understanding to enable this kind of functionality and be useful airflow has to think about DAG like an instance but not each task and context has to be the same/shared for the whole DAG to pass all the data between steps. 

So I just would like to have some insights about future logic for this functionality. To avoid going in wrong direction.

Thanks,
Andrey

First thank you for doing this! I created the PR as a placeholder for the discussion.

First I'm not sure what to do with `kt_renewer.py` and `security_util.py`. Is it possible that security_util ins't used anywhere? I couldn't find a reference to it. 

And for `kt_renewer` is forked out of the Hue project right? I guess it's small enough to hold it here (as opposed to having Airflow depend on Hue...). Maybe we need to put it under an `ext` folder and rename it to something more meaningful.

Apart from that everything seems reasonable upon first read.
OK sounds like a good idea!

ah. @jlowin - you are correct, those  parameters were supposed to be passed back through to the execute fn on the cursor, but it appears that they aren't doing that -- that would be the expected behavior imho.

nice catch!
I'm not sure if I understand the question but you can have a function that returns different DAG instances from different parameters.
Nice!
@jlowin #430 was merged, do you still see the circular imports? I don't see them on my end

For example:
I have a DAG that is for calculate some game standard KPIs. The data sources of the Games schema are same. But the database connection is different.
I want to start multiple Dag Instances, the DAG instances use the same Dag and different Environment variable(such as the DB connections) as start Dag params.

Thanks! 

`kt_renewer` does exactly what is named being a kerberos ticket renewer ;-). It is indeed forked out of the hue project, but it is also a port, although minor, to make it work in the airflow context. 

`security_util.py` is not used at the moment, it will however help with porting hooks to support kerberized services. I might need to change the example HiveCliHook to use it to get the fqdn from `security_utils.py` instead of getting it from `os.socket` as in multi-homed servers it might not give the correct name.

Instead of putting it into `ext` I would suggest `security` and then rename `security_util.py` to `util.py`. This reason for this is that for example a (future) yarn executor in a secure context will become reliant on having kerberos authentication available. Besides that putting it into `ext` would make it seem a bit slapped on which does not raise confidence with a certain public :-). But of course it is just semantics.

I can update the PR to have things moved. Let me know.

@txominpelu @garthcn @pharoson @mistercrunch 

Im am working on adding doAs functionality for the HiveCliHook. And I am wondering what I should take for a user that is being proxied. Is should this be the user mentioned as the login in the connection settings or should this be the owner that is set within a DAG?

From my perspective both have their downsides: access to connections is unauthenticated (every user has access to a connection) and thus this creates a risk of abuse and the same goes for owners of DAGs.

What would be the best approach?

edit: I just checked, but a hook doesn't know about a DAG owner so for now I will just use the login when configured to do so.
Seems ok now!
+1 Any update on this issue?

Can someone confirm that this is still a problem with the recent changes in trunk?

If so I'll try to find time to reproduce the bug and dig in. In the meantime running the commands with `--local` should work without problems.

Yeah, for instance you an write a function that instantiate and return a DAG object, to which you pass a different dictionary of `default_args` for instance.

Here's a heavily simplified example:

```
def make_dag(dag_id, default_args):
    dag = DAG(dag_id=dag_id, default_args=default_args)
    # create your tasks and associate them
    return dag
foo = make_dag('foo', {'mysql_conn_id': 'foo'})
bar = make_dag('foo', {'mysql_conn_id': 'bar'})
```
Sounds good, what about a security folder with `utils.py` and `kerberos.py`?
![img](http://www.reactiongifs.com/r/atpthrd.gif)
I pulled the branch and opened a dozen of charts on my end and only a few actually worked. I'll have to dig in and do some work to make this work.
I'm having problems with SqlAlchemy when setting my connection URI to `mysql+pymysql://`, I'll have to dig deeper before I can merge this.
Moved this PR locally to https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/pull/442, closing

You could add a flag "run_as_owner" in the operator and leave the choice to the user, fall back on the connection's information.

I think clearly the goal here is to make Airflow work with a Kerberosed Hive service, not to secure Airflow itself, that's bigger challenge that would start with securing the `Connection` access in some sort of vault that would require authentication. 

Airflow is still an "all or nothing" type of service for the time being.

Ok, I agree with the additional setting in the connections settings that sets whether login or owner should be used. This leaves some influence to an administrator.

BTW this is not just Hive but also (potentially) spark etc, so a bit of a generic pattern would be nice :)
@mistercrunch changes are implemented including owner/login support for HiveCliHook with beeline
What's the type of `params['tables']`? Is it picklable?
Heh, not sure. I was hoping you could give insight since the code throwing the error is from Airflow's library, specifically https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/blob/master/airflow/models.py#L1015
@mistercrunch done!
Just asking if it is possible to set Variables in code(like in some hook class). Cause I want to save the http connection cookies as variables.
Thanks for reporting this bug. https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/pull/449 should address it.
closes https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/issues/436
I got it. Let's me try. Thank you!
Never mind, I found my answer here: https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/issues/220

Do you know which lib needed GCC? `python-mysql`? Did you install subpackages?

Also if you want to install python packages in userspace you may want to check out `virtualenv`
Looks like the problem is that the pickle is incomplete, it should have a `params` attribute but doesn't. There are no codepaths that I know that can cause a task to not have a `params` attribute

I have an open issue #406 that our DAG is a bit large so it has to be stored in MySQL as a longblob. Could the pickling be failing silently due to its size?

FWIW, running a backfill on the whole DAG (without specifying a task filter) does succeed, and that probably pickles the DAG since CeleryExecutor is specified.
Woot thanks for the quick fix @jlowin!
Any advice on testing this function manually @mistercrunch ?
@mistercrunch is storing the framework id as a variable, as suggested by @kapil-malik, fine with you?

Is it just a single value? Your options are:
- the config file: if we expect only one framework
- as a Connection if we expect that many frameworks can coexist for an Airflow cluster
- settings.py / airflow_local_settings.py as an alternative to the .cfg file
- variables (this would set a precedent as no Airflow mechanics are using variables as of now)

Connections are nice for many reasons, I think I'd go with that.

I think the way I tested the SLA feature before was by setting an artificial SLA on a specific DAG that would be partially processed and running the scheduler only for that DAG (`airflow scheduler -d foo_dag`). You need to have email configured properly on that box to actually test it.

It looks like if i use a different `dag_id` it works. Is there a cache? 
I might have used the default `2015-06-01` for `dag_id = 'XYZ'` early on but then I cancelled and changed the date to 2015-09-23. Now it doesn't respect the start date for the same  dag_id. Once i changed `dag_id='abc'`, it worked fine

start_date is only used when "seeding" task (running for the first time), from that point on it adds the schedule_interval to the latest task instance.

From memory, the scheduler reloads the pipeline definition when it detects that the file has changed or every 10 runs.

Does this happen consistently? It seems very odd to me. 

At Airbnb we have many DAGs that can't be pickled because they use macros that aren't picklable, so we tend to use `backfill --local` which forces a local executor, does that work for you as a fallback?

Otherwise to debug it you'd have to fire up an ipython shell, pickle the DAG by hand, unpickle it and compare the two objects, try to understand why the one that comes back has missing params. That's pretty involved...

Ah, good call on using a batch insert. However, I think we would want to use the insert_lists (plural), as opposed to the insert_list function you linked. The function is not documented in https://pyvertica.readthedocs.org/en/latest/ because it looks like that's pointing to v1.5.2, and insert_lists was introduced in 1.5.3.

But if you looks here: https://pypi.python.org/pypi/pyvertica under the 1.5.3 summary it says: "add insert_lists method to VerticaBatch. This method takes multiple lists, converts them to rows, and invokes a single insert rather than one insert per row." So it looks like this is what we want?

I don't know why /latest/ points to 1.5.2, looks like the project is past 1.6, so I think the method should be stable.
@artwr I thought you might have a solution to this. Essentially, I notice my command is not making it as a single command in the SSH command.

Would throwing some backslash and line breaks help? Is this some sort of jinja "feature"?

```
ssh -o 'StrictHostKeyChecking no' -i ~/.ssh/id_rsa root@{{ params.import_spark_cluster_ip }} '. /root/.bash_profile; ~/run_check_files.sh {{ execution_date.strftime('%s') }} \
{{ execution_date.strftime('%s') }} {{ params.ENV }} {{ params.VALIDATE_INGEST_PARQUET_S3_PATH }} \
{{ params.SPARK_CLUSTER_URI }}'
```
Thanks!
Is anything else required to get this PR merged?
Sure. But shouldn't the scheduler pick up the new start_date on restart for the same dag_id?
Maybe it should skip ahead to the new start_date but that is not the current behavior. It's documented in both BaseOperator and The Scheduler.
I vote for skip ahead b/c I can't use the same dag_id anymore. will close issue for now. this can be a feature enhancement.

Wait. You can clear the state (from the UI or CLI) and it will restart at start_date. You can also "mark success" on the run right before the one you want as your new start_date and the scheduler will pick it up from there.
oh ok. `airflow clear dag_id` from CLI works for me. In the UI, that dag is marked as success already.

Got it, that is the expected behavior, the `upstream_failed` tasks need to be cleared in order to be re-evaluated. Luckily it easy to do this from the CLI and not too hard from the UI.

`upstream_failed` as all other task instance states in Airflow is not a logical state, it is persistent. Marking tasks `upstream_failed` allows for the scheduler to move on an not accumulate more dependencies to check at each run. It's important to keep the scheduler's worker close to O(n) in relation to the number of tasks.

There could be more logic in this area (recursing through downstream tasks on "mark success", and clearing the state), but it may be more tricky than it first seems (trigger_rules, other dependencies, ...)
Nice looking DAG btw!
Thanks CLI `airflow clear` solved it. unclear on the UI trick as that DAG is marked success already.
@mistercrunch Good catch. Fixed in https://github.com/kerzhner/airflow/commit/8f642753fb701801aad5d23ec2006697b3657335.

You could click each children and clear with include downstream, you could clear that task with include downstream and quickly mark success right after, before the scheduler has time to retrigger the task...
